documents.title: Fever Management Guidelines
documents.content:
Fever is a common symptom that indicates the body is fighting an infection.

For adults with fever:
- Rest and stay hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids
- Take acetaminophen (paracetamol) or ibuprofen to reduce fever and discomfort
- Monitor temperature regularly
- Seek medical attention if fever persists for more than 3 days, exceeds 39.4°C (103°F), or is accompanied by severe symptoms like difficulty breathing, chest pain, or confusion

For children with fever:
- Ensure adequate fluid intake
- Use age-appropriate fever reducers (acetaminophen or ibuprofen) following dosage guidelines
- Seek immediate medical attention if child is under 3 months with any fever, or if fever is above 40°C (104°F)
- Watch for signs of dehydration or unusual behavior

documents.title: Chest Pain Red Flags
documents.content:
Chest pain can be a sign of serious medical conditions and requires immediate evaluation in certain situations.

Red flag symptoms requiring immediate emergency care:
- Severe chest pain that radiates to arm, neck, or jaw
- Chest pain accompanied by shortness of breath, sweating, or nausea
- Chest pain in someone with known heart disease or risk factors
- Chest pain that worsens with exertion
- Chest pain with dizziness or fainting

If experiencing any red flag symptoms, seek emergency medical care immediately. Do not delay.

For non-urgent chest pain:
- Rest and avoid activities that trigger the pain
- Monitor symptoms and note any changes
- Consider evaluation within 24-48 hours if symptoms persist or worsen

documents.title: Common Cold and Flu Management
documents.content:
The common cold and influenza (flu) are viral respiratory infections. While similar, flu symptoms are typically more severe.

Self-care for cold and flu:
- Rest and allow your body to recover
- Stay hydrated with water, herbal teas, or clear broths
- Use saline nasal sprays or rinses for congestion
- Gargle with warm salt water for sore throat
- Use humidifier or steam to ease breathing
- Over-the-counter medications can help with symptoms
- Wash hands frequently to prevent spread

When to seek medical care:
- Symptoms persist beyond 10 days
- High fever (above 38.9°C or 102°F) that doesn't respond to treatment
- Difficulty breathing or chest pain
- Persistent cough with colored mucus

documents.title: Headache Management
documents.content:
Headaches are common and most are not serious. However, certain symptoms require immediate medical attention.

Self-care for common headaches:
- Rest in a quiet, dark room
- Apply cold or warm compress to head or neck
- Stay hydrated
- Take over-the-counter pain relievers (paracetamol or ibuprofen)
- Practice relaxation techniques
- Avoid known triggers (stress, certain foods, lack of sleep)

Red flags requiring immediate medical attention:
- Sudden, severe headache (thunderclap headache)
- Headache after head injury
- Headache with fever, stiff neck, confusion, or vision changes
- New headache pattern in people over 50
- Headache that worsens despite treatment

Prevention:
- Maintain regular sleep schedule
- Stay hydrated
- Manage stress
- Limit caffeine and alcohol

documents.title: Diarrhea and Dehydration Management
documents.content:
Diarrhea is common and usually resolves within a few days. The main concern is preventing dehydration.

Self-care for diarrhea:
- Drink plenty of fluids (water, oral rehydration solution, clear broths)
- Avoid milk products temporarily
- Eat bland foods when able (rice, bananas, toast)
- Avoid caffeine, alcohol, and fatty foods
- Rest and allow body to recover

Oral rehydration solution (ORS):
- Available at pharmacies or can be made at home
- Essential for replacing lost fluids and electrolytes
- Give frequently in small amounts

Signs of dehydration requiring medical attention:
- Very dark urine or no urination for 8+ hours
- Extreme thirst
- Dry mouth and lips
- Dizziness or lightheadedness
- Sunken eyes
- Confusion or weakness

Seek immediate care if:
- Diarrhea lasts more than 3 days
- Severe abdominal pain
- Blood in stool
- High fever (above 38.9°C)
- Signs of severe dehydration

documents.title: Cough Management
documents.content:
Coughs are common and help clear airways. Most coughs improve within 3 weeks.

Types of coughs:
- Dry cough: No mucus production
- Productive cough: Brings up mucus or phlegm
- Acute: Lasts less than 3 weeks
- Chronic: Lasts more than 8 weeks

Self-care for coughs:
- Stay hydrated to thin mucus
- Use honey (for adults and children over 1 year)
- Try steam inhalation or humidifier
- Avoid irritants (smoke, strong odors)
- Prop head up when sleeping
- Use cough drops or lozenges
- Over-the-counter cough suppressants if needed

Seek medical attention if:
- Cough lasts more than 3 weeks
- Coughing up blood
- Difficulty breathing or chest pain
- High fever or chills
- Thick, discolored mucus
- Wheezing or shortness of breath
- Unexplained weight loss

For children:
- Never give honey to infants under 1 year
- Avoid cough medicines in children under 6 years
- Seek medical attention if child has difficulty breathing

documents.title: Minor Wound and Cut Care
documents.content:
Proper wound care prevents infection and promotes healing.

Immediate care for minor cuts:
1. Wash hands thoroughly
2. Stop bleeding by applying gentle pressure with clean cloth
3. Clean wound with clean water (soap around wound, not in it)
4. Apply antibiotic ointment if available
5. Cover with sterile bandage or dressing
6. Keep wound clean and dry

Daily wound care:
- Change bandage daily or when wet/dirty
- Clean wound gently each time
- Watch for signs of infection
- Keep wound elevated if possible to reduce swelling

Signs of infection requiring medical attention:
- Increased redness, swelling, or warmth
- Pus or foul-smelling drainage
- Increased pain
- Red streaks extending from wound
- Fever
- Wound not healing after several days

Seek immediate medical care for:
- Deep or large wounds
- Wounds that won't stop bleeding
- Wounds from animal or human bites
- Wounds with embedded objects
- Signs of infection
- Wounds on face or joints
- Puncture wounds
- Concern about need for tetanus shot

Tetanus prevention:
- Ensure tetanus vaccination is up to date
- Booster needed every 10 years

documents.title: HIV Prevention and Testing
documents.content:
HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) can be prevented and managed effectively with modern treatments.

Prevention methods:
- Consistent and correct condom use
- Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for high-risk individuals
- Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) within 72 hours of potential exposure
- Use of sterile needles (never share)
- Treatment as prevention: People living with HIV who maintain undetectable viral loads cannot transmit HIV sexually

Testing:
- Regular testing is important for sexually active individuals
- Confidential and often free testing available at clinics
- Rapid tests provide results in 20 minutes
- Window period: HIV may not show on test for 3 months after exposure
- Know your status and your partner's status

If you test positive:
- HIV is a manageable chronic condition with treatment
- Antiretroviral therapy (ART) allows people to live long, healthy lives
- Early treatment is crucial
- Treatment prevents transmission to others
- Confidential support services available

When to test:
- After unprotected sex
- Before starting new relationship
- If partner has HIV
- After sexual assault
- If sharing needles
- During pregnancy
- If experiencing symptoms (fever, rash, swollen lymph nodes)

Emergency situations:
- PEP must be started within 72 hours of exposure
- Seek immediate medical care after potential exposure

documents.title: Tuberculosis (TB) Awareness and Screening
documents.content:
Tuberculosis (TB) is a bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs. It is curable with proper treatment.

Common symptoms:
- Persistent cough lasting more than 2 weeks
- Coughing up blood or mucus
- Chest pain
- Unexplained weight loss
- Night sweats
- Fever
- Fatigue
- Loss of appetite

Who should get tested:
- Anyone with symptoms listed above
- Close contacts of people with TB
- People living with HIV
- Healthcare workers
- People in crowded living conditions
- People with weakened immune systems

Testing and diagnosis:
- Skin test (Mantoux test) or blood test
- Chest X-ray if test is positive
- Sputum test to confirm active TB
- Testing is confidential and often free

Treatment:
- TB is curable with 6-9 months of antibiotics
- Must complete full course of treatment
- Never stop treatment early, even if feeling better
- Incomplete treatment can lead to drug-resistant TB
- Treatment is often provided free of charge

Prevention:
- Cover mouth when coughing or sneezing
- Ensure good ventilation in living spaces
- Seek early treatment if symptomatic
- Complete prescribed preventive therapy if recommended
- BCG vaccination (varies by country)

Important:
- TB is spread through air when infected person coughs or sneezes
- Not spread through handshakes, food, or surfaces
- Treatment makes you non-infectious within 2-3 weeks
- Stigma-free care is a right

Seek immediate testing if:
- Persistent cough for more than 2 weeks
- Coughing up blood
- Contact with person diagnosed with TB
- Experiencing multiple symptoms listed above

documents.title: Contraception Methods and Information
documents.content:
Various contraception methods are available to prevent pregnancy. Choosing the right method depends on individual needs, health, and preferences.

Short-acting methods:
- Condoms: 85-98% effective, also prevent STIs
- Birth control pills: 91-99% effective with consistent use
- Emergency contraception: Can prevent pregnancy up to 5 days after unprotected sex

Long-acting reversible methods:
- Intrauterine devices (IUDs): 99% effective, lasts 3-10 years
- Contraceptive implant: 99% effective, lasts 3-5 years
- Injectable contraceptives: 94-99% effective, given every 3 months

Permanent methods:
- Tubal ligation (female sterilization)
- Vasectomy (male sterilization)
- Over 99% effective

Considerations when choosing:
- Effectiveness
- Ease of use
- Health conditions
- Side effects
- STI protection needs
- Future pregnancy plans
- Cost and accessibility

Dual protection:
- Using condoms plus another method
- Protects against both pregnancy and STIs
- Recommended for optimal protection

Access to contraception:
- Consultation with healthcare provider
- Many methods available at clinics
- Some methods available without prescription
- Confidential services available

Emergency contraception:
- Available without prescription in many countries
- Most effective when taken as soon as possible
- Can be taken up to 5 days after unprotected sex
- Does not cause abortion
- Does not affect future fertility

Important:
- No contraception method is 100% effective except abstinence
- Only condoms protect against STIs
- Contraception does not affect future fertility (except sterilization)
- Everyone has the right to access contraception
- Confidential counseling available

documents.title: Pregnancy Warning Signs
documents.content:
Most pregnancies progress normally, but certain symptoms require immediate medical attention.

Seek immediate medical care for:
- Vaginal bleeding or spotting
- Severe abdominal pain or cramping
- Severe headache or vision changes
- Sudden swelling of face, hands, or feet
- Fever over 38°C (100.4°F)
- Burning or pain when urinating
- Fluid leaking from vagina
- Decreased or no fetal movement (after 20 weeks)
- Severe vomiting (unable to keep food or water down)
- Signs of preterm labor (regular contractions before 37 weeks)

Danger signs in late pregnancy:
- Water breaking before 37 weeks
- Regular contractions before 37 weeks
- Severe and persistent headache
- Vision problems (blurred vision, seeing spots)
- Upper abdominal pain
- Rapid weight gain or severe swelling
- Baby moving less than usual

Routine prenatal care:
- Regular checkups as scheduled
- Take prenatal vitamins with folic acid
- Eat balanced, nutritious diet
- Stay hydrated
- Avoid alcohol, tobacco, and recreational drugs
- Discuss all medications with healthcare provider
- Get adequate rest
- Gentle exercise as approved by provider

Common pregnancy discomforts (usually normal):
- Morning sickness (usually improves after first trimester)
- Fatigue
- Frequent urination
- Heartburn
- Backache
- Mild swelling of feet

When to call healthcare provider:
- Any concerning symptoms
- Questions about medications
- Signs of infection
- Unusual discharge
- Concerns about baby's movements
- Emotional health concerns

Emergency situations requiring immediate care:
- Heavy vaginal bleeding
- Severe abdominal pain
- Signs of stroke (sudden weakness, facial drooping, speech difficulty)
- Seizures
- Loss of consciousness
- Thoughts of harming self or baby

documents.title: Mental Health and Stress Management
documents.content:
Mental health is as important as physical health. Taking care of your mental wellbeing is essential.

Signs you may need support:
- Persistent sadness or low mood
- Loss of interest in activities you usually enjoy
- Changes in sleep (sleeping too much or too little)
- Changes in appetite or weight
- Difficulty concentrating
- Feeling overwhelmed or unable to cope
- Excessive worry or anxiety
- Irritability or anger
- Withdrawing from others
- Thoughts of self-harm or suicide

Stress management techniques:
- Regular physical activity
- Adequate sleep (7-9 hours for adults)
- Healthy eating
- Deep breathing exercises
- Meditation or mindfulness
- Talking to trusted friends or family
- Limiting alcohol and avoiding drugs
- Setting realistic goals and priorities
- Taking breaks and time for self-care
- Engaging in hobbies or activities you enjoy

When to seek professional help:
- Symptoms persist for more than 2 weeks
- Symptoms interfere with daily life
- Difficulty functioning at work, school, or home
- Relationship problems
- Thoughts of self-harm or suicide
- Using alcohol or drugs to cope
- Physical symptoms with no medical cause

Types of support available:
- Counseling or therapy
- Support groups
- Medication (if recommended by healthcare provider)
- Crisis helplines
- Community mental health services
- Online resources and apps

Emergency situations:
- Thoughts of suicide or self-harm
- Thoughts of harming others
- Hearing voices or seeing things others don't
- Unable to care for yourself
- Severe panic attacks

Important reminders:
- Mental health conditions are common and treatable
- Seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness
- You are not alone
- Recovery is possible
- Stigma-free care is your right
- Confidential services are available

Crisis support:
- National crisis helplines available 24/7
- Emergency departments can provide immediate help
- Reach out to healthcare provider
- Tell someone you trust

Self-care for mental health:
- Stay connected with others
- Maintain routines
- Set boundaries
- Practice self-compassion
- Celebrate small achievements
- Be patient with yourself
- Remember that bad days don't last forever

documents.title: Malaria Prevention and Treatment
documents.content:
Malaria is a serious mosquito-borne disease common in many tropical and subtropical regions. Prevention and early treatment are crucial.

Symptoms of malaria:
- High fever and chills
- Severe headache
- Sweating
- Muscle aches
- Nausea and vomiting
- Fatigue
- Symptoms typically appear 10-15 days after mosquito bite

Prevention methods:
- Sleep under insecticide-treated bed nets
- Use mosquito repellent on exposed skin
- Wear long sleeves and pants, especially at dawn and dusk
- Keep windows and doors screened or closed
- Eliminate standing water around home
- Use indoor insecticide sprays
- Take antimalarial medication if prescribed for your area

When to seek immediate medical care:
- Any fever in malaria-endemic area
- Severe headache with fever
- Confusion or altered consciousness
- Difficulty breathing
- Seizures
- Severe anemia symptoms (extreme fatigue, pale skin)
- Dark or bloody urine

Treatment:
- Malaria is curable with prompt treatment
- Treatment must be started as soon as possible
- Complete full course of prescribed medication
- Follow-up testing may be needed
- Never self-medicate or share malaria medication

Special considerations:
- Pregnant women: At higher risk, need special prevention and treatment
- Children: At higher risk, need age-appropriate doses
- Travelers: May need preventive medication before visiting endemic areas

Important facts:
- Malaria can be life-threatening if untreated
- Drug-resistant malaria exists in some areas
- Having malaria once doesn't provide complete immunity
- Rapid diagnostic tests are available
- Treatment is most effective when started early

Pregnancy and malaria:
- Pregnant women are at increased risk
- Malaria can cause miscarriage, stillbirth, or low birth weight
- Preventive treatment available during pregnancy
- Use bed nets and repellent
- Attend all prenatal appointments

documents.title: Diabetes Management and Self-Care
documents.content:
Diabetes is a chronic condition that affects how your body processes blood sugar. With proper management, people with diabetes can live long, healthy lives.

Types of diabetes:
- Type 1: Body doesn't produce insulin
- Type 2: Body doesn't use insulin properly (most common)
- Gestational: Develops during pregnancy

Key self-care practices:
- Monitor blood glucose as recommended by healthcare provider
- Take medications exactly as prescribed
- Follow a balanced meal plan with controlled carbohydrate intake
- Engage in regular physical activity (at least 150 minutes per week)
- Maintain healthy weight
- Check feet daily for cuts, sores, or changes
- Attend all scheduled healthcare appointments
- Get regular eye exams
- Monitor blood pressure

Healthy eating for diabetes:
- Choose whole grains over refined grains
- Include vegetables and fruits
- Limit sugary drinks and foods
- Control portion sizes
- Spread carbohydrates throughout the day
- Stay hydrated with water
- Limit saturated fats and trans fats

Physical activity:
- Helps control blood glucose levels
- Improves insulin sensitivity
- Helps with weight management
- Reduces cardiovascular risk
- Start slowly and build up gradually
- Check blood glucose before and after exercise
- Carry fast-acting carbohydrate during exercise

Blood glucose monitoring:
- Follow testing schedule recommended by provider
- Keep a log of results
- Know your target ranges
- Understand what affects your levels
- Share results with healthcare team

Foot care:
- Check feet daily for cuts, blisters, redness, or swelling
- Wash feet daily with lukewarm water
- Dry thoroughly, especially between toes
- Moisturize but not between toes
- Wear comfortable, well-fitting shoes
- Never go barefoot
- Trim toenails carefully
- Report any foot problems immediately

Warning signs requiring immediate medical attention:
- Very high blood glucose (above 16.7 mmol/L or 300 mg/dL)
- Very low blood glucose (below 3.9 mmol/L or 70 mg/dL)
- Signs of diabetic ketoacidosis: excessive thirst, frequent urination, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, confusion, fruity breath odor
- Chest pain or pressure
- Difficulty breathing
- Severe hypoglycemia: confusion, loss of consciousness, seizures
- Foot wounds that don't heal
- Vision changes
- Numbness or tingling in extremities

Hypoglycemia (low blood sugar):
- Symptoms: shakiness, sweating, hunger, confusion, dizziness, rapid heartbeat
- Treat immediately with 15 grams fast-acting carbohydrate
- Recheck glucose after 15 minutes
- If still low, repeat treatment
- Follow with a small snack if next meal is more than 1 hour away

Preventing complications:
- Keep blood glucose in target range
- Control blood pressure and cholesterol
- Don't smoke
- Attend regular medical checkups
- Get annual eye exams
- Have feet checked at every visit
- Get kidney function tests as recommended
- Take medications as prescribed

Living with diabetes:
- Wear medical identification
- Educate family and friends about diabetes
- Know how to handle sick days
- Plan ahead for meals and activities
- Join support groups if helpful
- Manage stress
- Get adequate sleep

Important reminders:
- Diabetes is manageable with proper care
- Small changes make a big difference
- Regular monitoring prevents complications
- You are not alone - support is available
- Never stop medications without consulting provider

documents.title: Hypertension (High Blood Pressure) Management
documents.content:
Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is a common condition that can lead to serious health problems if left untreated. It often has no symptoms but can be managed effectively.

Understanding blood pressure:
- Measured as systolic/diastolic (e.g., 120/80 mmHg)
- Normal: Less than 120/80
- Elevated: 120-129/less than 80
- High (Stage 1): 130-139/80-89
- High (Stage 2): 140 or higher/90 or higher
- Hypertensive crisis: Higher than 180/120 (seek immediate care)

Lifestyle modifications:
- Reduce sodium intake to less than 2,300 mg per day
- Follow DASH diet (rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean protein)
- Maintain healthy weight
- Exercise regularly (at least 150 minutes per week)
- Limit alcohol consumption
- Don't smoke or use tobacco
- Manage stress through relaxation techniques
- Get adequate sleep (7-9 hours per night)

Dietary changes:
- Eat more fruits and vegetables
- Choose whole grains
- Include low-fat dairy products
- Select lean proteins (fish, poultry, beans)
- Limit foods high in saturated fat
- Avoid processed and packaged foods (often high in sodium)
- Read food labels for sodium content
- Use herbs and spices instead of salt

Physical activity:
- Aim for at least 30 minutes most days
- Start slowly if not currently active
- Include aerobic exercise (walking, swimming, cycling)
- Add strength training twice per week
- Even small amounts of activity help
- Break activity into shorter sessions if needed

Medication management:
- Take medications exactly as prescribed
- Never stop medications without consulting provider
- Take medications at the same time each day
- Don't skip doses
- Inform provider of any side effects
- Never share medications
- Keep track of all medications
- Ask about interactions with other medications or supplements

Home blood pressure monitoring:
- Use validated home blood pressure monitor
- Measure at same time each day
- Sit quietly for 5 minutes before measuring
- Use proper technique (arm supported at heart level)
- Take multiple readings and record all results
- Share log with healthcare provider
- Don't adjust medications based on single reading

When to seek immediate medical care:
- Blood pressure reading higher than 180/120
- Severe headache
- Chest pain
- Difficulty breathing
- Severe anxiety
- Vision changes
- Confusion
- Nosebleed that won't stop
- Severe dizziness

Complications of uncontrolled hypertension:
- Heart attack
- Stroke
- Heart failure
- Kidney disease
- Vision loss
- Sexual dysfunction
- Peripheral artery disease

Prevention and control:
- Regular health checkups
- Blood pressure screening
- Know your numbers
- Follow treatment plan consistently
- Lifestyle modifications are essential
- Medications work best with lifestyle changes

Special considerations:
- Pregnancy: High blood pressure can be dangerous, requires close monitoring
- Diabetes: Blood pressure control is especially important
- Kidney disease: May require stricter blood pressure targets
- Older adults: May need different target ranges

Working with healthcare team:
- Attend all scheduled appointments
- Ask questions about your treatment
- Report any medication side effects
- Discuss concerns about costs or access to medications
- Request referrals if needed
- Keep list of all medications and supplements

Important reminders:
- Hypertension usually has no symptoms (silent killer)
- Regular monitoring is essential
- Treatment is lifelong
- Lifestyle changes can reduce need for medications
- Small changes add up over time
- Support from family and friends helps
- Many people successfully manage hypertension
